John, you've talked about this a little bit in answer to prior questions, but – and you've talked about backward-looking market share, but is there anything you can tell us in terms of bid win rates or other competitive metrics that you track throughout the quarter to make us comfortable that the shortfall in orders outside the cable segment, I guess is primarily market and not a competitive issue for you? Were your order win rates or your bid win rates consistent with where you wanted them to be, and it was just simply a fall-off in orders, or what additional detail are you able to provide there, please?
I'm going to take a crack at it. But I'm going to let Rob take the first part, and then I will follow on on it as I think about how I want to answer it. Rob?

John, I think that some of the questions have revolved around our ability to convert pipeline into orders. And clearly as you've seen, state governments go through a series of elections in the United States. That's a period in which not a lot of projects are converted to orders as new governments get formed and decisions may be pushed out a quarter or two. It's a little bit harder getting orders in some of the state and local governments.

Clearly we've seen universities innovating and buying technology. Education is out there, but it's a little bit slow on getting E-Rate funding, which then funds some of those projects. So a little bit of this is around project funding and capture rather than wins and losses. And I think what you said is we're winning a lot of major franchises and opportunities, but converting those in orders will depend on the ability of an institution to actually fund and complete those projects, and therefore I don't think we're seeing any change in win rates.

So let's get more basic than that if we could, Rob, and then I'll take the second phase. In terms of when you go up against Juniper, when you go up against HP, when you go up against an IBM in a data center architectural play, are you seeing any fundamental change in terms of the win rates in this area?
No.

Yeah. And I just wanted Rob to say that rather than me for two reasons: First, is if you look at where we are, there is nobody that matches the CRS-3 and CRS-1, and the area where we were exposed at the edge that you all fairly criticized us on a year ago, we're taking market share, and I was very direct in terms of edge and wireless that you would probably see a major bump this next quarter alone.

In terms of access, we're at 87% market share according to that analyst. It doesn't get much better than that and we actually gained share. In terms of switching, might there be a quarter or two where numbers go up or down slightly? We do very well. In terms of are some of our competitors in installed accounts, when we start to win, saying, "I'll give you the product for free," so are you seeing some aggressive moves from some of them? You are seeing that in terms of direction.

But our win rates is very good. You go into data center. We are literally knocking off one service provider after another. We're knocking off enterprise account after enterprise account to already be at 40 that are $1 million plus in run rates there feels very good.

So I will give you that in terms of set-top boxes, Motorola gained market share this quarter. I will give you that in ANS and WAAS, which out of the nine areas I talked about, we have a couple good competitors there. But by the way, the seven areas that are all bigger than that and even higher strategically for Cisco, so both bigger market opportunity, et cetera, we're doing extremely well in.

In the wireless LAN just an example, a year ago, we had a little bit of a product mismatch with some of our competitors. Now we're ramping up at a very fast pace in terms of wireless LAN, and we took this most recent quarter 3 points on that.

So maybe you're seeing something we're not, but I'm very comfortable with where we are on products and this innovation engine is on fire. So I keep going back, an air pocket that we hit, not a dramatic one in terms of change, in terms of where we expect to be in two to three quarters from now. We feel pretty good about our momentum and the direction wise and the issues that we can control or influence, I think we're as strong as ever. So you can come back at me and invite anybody on the phone to come back, but where we are in terms of our product sets and the competitiveness, we're very, very good on that.
Thank you, John.
Okay. One last question, please.
Our last question comes from Jason Ader with William Blair.
Yes, thanks. It's real two quick housekeeping ones. Excluding the cable operators, John, what was the service provider order growth in Q1? And also what percentage of public sector is U.S. fed?

back into it. In terms of – I don't think I have the cable operators outside U.S. broken down, although cable operations in Europe actually grew and we did well on both traditional cable operations, as well as IP set-top boxes. Is that what you remember, Rob? Okay.

To the second part, the federal business in terms of our overall approach grew in the mid-teens and was very solid on that. State and local, that tends to be – go back and forth versus education, probably 45-55, or a 40-60 type of basis. State government was down pretty dramatically as I shared with you all. Local government was down a little bit.

In terms of education, as Rob alluded to, higher education is actually going well for us. Its growth rate was mid-teens or higher. And that's probably a pretty reasonable expectation going forward. For K1 through 12 and E-Rate is a little bit tougher, as you all know, in the marketplace. I think that was down slightly.

In terms of total federal business, which I was – and total government business in the U.S., I was giving you all time to see if one of you could do the math for me. I'd probably have to look at it in terms of basis, but 22, 24% probably of the U.S. business.
So I guess U.S. fed is 24% of the total U.S. or total public sector – total U.S. public sector or total global public sector?
Let me get the numbers and look at that on a follow-up rather than shoot from the hip. We're all looking at tables.

In terms of the business – remember, the Federal business is heavily weighted to the beginning of the fiscal year. So Q2 in Federal while we would anticipate good growth rates there, is not near as big as Q1. So there are seasonalities by segments within this and when orders occur within it overall.

But I think that the safe number to use is what we see on a global basis. It's 22% of our business is public sector. And our enterprise business is 23%, and our commercial business is 20%. So the 23% which is enterprise and the 20% commercial we feel very good about.

The government business, again, we think we're well positioned to win more than our fair share there, so I don't think you're going to see us have surprising market share losses unless I'm missing something in that category and we'll get our fair share over time. The one area that I do think that we have room for improvement on is the cable business, and part of that reminding everyone is also dependent on which customers you have, whether their order rates, etcetera, depend on which vendors they standardize on.
Great. Okay, thanks, Jason.

So we are going to close. Cisco's next quarterly conference call which will reflect our second quarter fiscal 2011 results will be on Wednesday, February 9, 2011, at 1:30 PM Pacific Time, 4:30 PM Eastern Time.

Additionally, downloadable Q1 FY '11 financial statements will be available following the call including revenue segments by product and geography. Income statements, full GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation information, balance sheets, and cash flow statements can be found on our website in the Investor Relations section. Just click on the financial reporting section of the website.

And again, I'd like to remind you that in light of Regulation Fair Disclosure, Cisco plans to retain its longstanding policy to not comment on its financial guidance during the quarter unless it is done through an explicit public disclosure.
Please call the Investor Relations department with any follow-up questions from this call. Thank you for your participation and ongoing support, and this concludes our call.

Thank you for participating in today's conference call. If you would like to listen to the call in its entirety, you may call 866-357-4205. For participants dialing outside the U.S., please dial 203-369-0122. This concludes today's call. You may disconnect at this time. Thank you.
